item.title: The 5 best web application frameworks: How to choose
item.dc:creator: svcselenium
item.description: As application development continues to evolve, the demandÂ for teams to rapidly deliver software that can scale andÂ evolve to meet customer
item.content:encoded:
As application development continues to evolve, the demandÂ for teams to rapidly deliver software that can scale andÂ evolve to meet customer needs hasÂ never been higher.Â Front-end development frameworks are keyÂ to makingÂ that happen.

TheseÂ frameworks areÂ where the work for the layout, logic, andÂ application is executed.Â TheseÂ browser-based systemsÂ requireÂ JavaScript, CSS, HTML, and other web-standard technologies.

So how do you choose which framework is best for you?Â Here are theÂ top five frameworks that development teams are using, based on my opinion and experiences, and what you need to know about them.

[ Learn best practices for reducing software defects with TechBeacon’s Guide. Plus: Get the report “Agile and DevOps Reduces Volume, Cost, and Impact of Production Defects” ]

Top front-end frameworks

Web browsers all compete to have the best support for open standards such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. There is much less work needed to test if technologies work across different web browsers. The five frameworks you should considerÂ are:

  • Angular
  • React
  • Vue
  • Ember
  • Svelte

The reviews that follow areÂ based on my experience and thatÂ of my teams. (I encourage you to leave anyÂ thoughts based onÂ your own experiencesÂ in the comments below.)

1. Angular

Angular arguably has the most extended history of any on this list. Initially developed by Google in 2010, itÂ was subsequently released as an open-source project. The framework consistently receives updates with significant releases typically deliveredÂ every six to nineÂ months. The current major release is version 9.1.Â 

Pros

There is strong developer support for Angular. The documentation on the site supporting Angular development is excellentÂ and, as a developer, you will find a lot of great how-toÂ videos on YouTube to get you started.

Also, Angular continues to evolve and meet the needs of web developers. To this end, the framework supports theÂ TypeScript language (a superset of JavaScript), a progressive web app architecture for multi-format solutions, and the M-V-C (model view controller) architecture.

Angular is alsoÂ a critical component of the MEAN development stack consisting of MongoDB, ExpressJS, Angular, and NodeJS.

Cons

Angular’s age can presentÂ a problem. In 2010, developers weren’t building mobile web apps, so for several years, additions were shoehorned into Angular to accommodateÂ them. In 2016,Â Angular was rewrittenÂ with TypeScript and released as Angular 4. The original version, AngularJS, was renamed as Angular.

Unfortunately, previous versions of AngularÂ aren’t compatible with the new TypeScript version in Angular 4. That’s important to know if any part of your organizations has used Angular and you’re thinking of going this direction for compatibility reasons.

Bottom line

Angular has grown and adapted to modern development needs. If you go this route, useÂ the newer Angular 4 and later versions for building Angular apps. And be sure to keep a close eye on the Angular blogÂ to keep up with the latest improvements to the framework.

[ Understand whatÂ your team needs to know to take advantage of test automation with TechBeacon’s Guide. Plus: Get the Buyer’s Guide For Software Test Automation Tools ]

2. React

Many development groups will choose either Angular or React as the base foundation for their web applications. The logic makes sense, and both are mature. Both deliver applications that can run massive web apps, and both have strong communities where developers can share information.

But where Angular went with TypeScript, React leverages JavaScript extensively.Â Facebook, along with individual contributors and other companies, maintainÂ React.

Pros

Some very large companiesâ€”includingÂ Facebook, Netflix, Dropbox, Airbnb, and Redditâ€”use React as their front-end framework. These sites receive millions of views per day. React has provedÂ itself to be able to scale and meet the needs of the most demanding web apps.

Additionally, the skills you learn for React also applyÂ to ReactNative, a framework that developers can use to build native applications that run on the iOS and Android mobile operating systems.

Cons

React is not easy to learn. The entire architecture is built in JavaScript, soÂ you must be an experiencedÂ developer to start with React.Â 

Bottom line

The learning curve with React is steep, but the result is a modular architecture that can support the most demanding websites. Facebook and the open-source community continue to invest in the growth of React, which ensures that investing in React will reward you for years into the future.

3. Vue

The selling point for Vue is the size of the framework. At only 20KB, this is one of the most lightweightÂ frameworks on the list. The inspiration for Vue came from work the original developer completed on Angular. In 2014, Vue was released as a slimmed-down alternative to Angular and has maintained a cult following ever since.

Pros

Much like Angular, getting up to speed with Vue is not difficult. You can leverage your skills with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. You can also build templates and components in Vue, much as you wouldÂ with ReactJS.Â 

Cons

Many developers rank Vue as a third-choiceÂ framework, behind Angular and React. To this end, the community supporting Vue is much smaller, and the development of the framework is not as robust as other, more popular frameworks.

Bottom line

Vue is an excellent alternative framework to learn and leverage as you need. It is a contending framework and could potentially be a smart alternative to Angular.

4.Â Ember

Ember is one of the younger frameworks on this list. Released in 2011, its focus isÂ on helping you buildÂ complexÂ web applications. It offers:

  • More productivityÂ right out of the box whenÂ compared to others on this list
  • Stability without stagnation
  • Support forÂ HTML5

With these principles and continuous development, Ember is now in use for many large and popular applications, such as Apple Music, LinkedIn, and Square.

Pros

The modular architecture and many hundreds of plugins make Ember a framework that gives you a lot right out of the starting gate. Also, solutions built with Ember can be converted into native applications such as Apple Music.

Cons

Ember leverages modules to extend the framework. The challenge as a developer is knowing which modules you should be using. Besides, there is a learning curve required to get started with Ember.

Bottom line

Ember is evolving quickly into a mature and stable alternative for building web apps and native appsÂ when compared to React.Native and Angular.

Svelte

Svelte is the anti-framework framework. There are issuesÂ with some frameworks,Â such as a large codebase required to run scripts.Â Svelte, released in 2016, is driving the campaign to reduce the challenges of someÂ traditional frameworks.

For instance, a simple To Do MVPÂ application written with Svelte will weigh in at 3.6KB, whereas the same app written for React tops 45KBâ€”10Â times bigger.Â 

Svelte can create tiny apps because ofÂ the model it uses for building applications. Other frameworks, included the onesÂ listed above, rely on the web browser do the bulk of the work.

With Svelte, you write components with CSS, HTML, and JavaScript, and then Svelte compiles the code into JavaScript modules. The result is that the browser does not have to do as much work. Which, in turn, means you can write more complex applications.

Pros

JavaScript modules are an effective way of speeding up any JavaScript application. The approach Svelte brings is to increase the efficiency of your apps.

Cons

Many web developers have not worked with JavaScriptÂ modules. The whole approach Svelte offers is very different, and, because Svelte is the new kid on the block, the developer community is still growing.

Bottom line

Svelte offers an interesting approach to Web app development. There is merit in working with JavaScript modules, and the model Svelte offers is one that developers should experiment with. With that said, Svelte is thin on documentation. So, for the foreseeable future,Â treat Svelte as experimental.

Go beyond web apps

The focus of these frameworksÂ is web apps, but that is no longerÂ the world we live in. Back-end frameworks and accelerators also play a huge role in app development these days. (Those are topics go beyond the scope of this article, but need to be mentioned.)

Important accelerators include cloud, open-source tools, DevOps methodologies and security. But in many ways, the most critical accelerator is yourÂ mindset.Â As a modern developer, you must adopt a mindset of constant learning to continually improve the delivery model to meet the ever-increasing demands of your customers.

You must be able to effectively deliver solutions that can scale across all of the platforms your customers use. The combined powerÂ of front-end, back-end, and accelerators will give you the edge you need.

item.title: 6Â proven metrics for DevOps success
item.dc:creator: svcselenium
item.description: Many teamsÂ struggle to identify the key performance indicators that will demonstrate to management why DevOps matters and how it affects
item.content:encoded:
Many teamsÂ struggle to identify the key performance indicators that will demonstrate to management why DevOps matters and how it affects business results. Not having the right metricsÂ is just one of the many ways that DevOps initiatives fail.

Visualizing objective, automated metrics makes them easier to understand.Â That’s why choosingÂ the right DevOps metrics is key. Here are sixÂ that have worked for my teamÂ at IBM, why they were chosen, and theÂ improvementsÂ seen as a result.Â 

[ Continuous delivery and release automation (CDRA) demands speed and quality. Find out how in TechBeacon’s guide to CDRA. Plus: Get the Forrester Wave on CDRA.Â  ]

1. Availability andÂ uptime

InÂ the book Accelerate,Â by Nicole Forsgren, Jez Humble, and Gene Kim,Â one of the four key software delivery metrics is “time to restore service.”Â UptimeÂ isÂ essentiallyÂ a way to aggregate this metric over time.Â Â 

My team calculates availability by taking the total time of all outages reported by our primary production monitor for each service, subtracting that from the total time, and then dividing by the total time.Â 

OurÂ availabilityÂ dashboard calculatesÂ this on demand for any date range.Â Most of our services have agreed to a service-level objective (SLO) of 99.95% uptime, with a few committing to 99.85% instead.

Our general manager reviews the uptime numbers for each of our production services quarterly. ThisÂ motivatesÂ teams to:

  • Make sure their production monitors are accurately measuring the true end user experience
  • Focus on improving the availability of services that aren’t meeting their goals
  • CelebrateÂ when they meet their SLO

2. Work in progress

The Toyota Production System of lean manufacturing taught us that limiting work in progress (batch sizes) helps teams improve overall throughput.Â Put another way, it’s better to finish one project today than to chip away at 10 projects and finish none of them.

With our work-in-progress metric added to our dashboard, my team can simply countÂ the number of open issues of each typeÂ (story, defect, task).Â When the number gets too high, it’s time to stop taking on new work and focus on what has alreadyÂ beenÂ started.Â That improves our overall velocity.

[ Learn the secrets of successful DevOps initiatives in TechBeaconâ€™sÂ Guide. Plus: Get theÂ Optimizing DevOps Initiatives: Both Sides of the DevOps DivideÂ report ]

3. Repository speed

Pull requests represent value waiting to be delivered to production.Â The repository speed score is based on the time from submission to merge (i.e., review duration) of GitHub pull requests, over the last 30 days.Â A perfect score is given when the average time per pull request comes in at zero to twoÂ weekdays (M-F), decreasing to a score of zero at fiveÂ weekdays.Â Â 

Old pull requests can get lost, affecting the repository speed metric. When you’re working with more than one repository, it’sÂ difficult to keep track of outstanding pull requests.

One newÂ featureÂ shows where all outstanding pull requests for every repository the squad owns are shown, highlighting the ones that are old, and some squads review these in their daily stand-up.Â By highlighting old pull requests waiting for review, we ensure that our developers focus their code review efforts where they areÂ needed.

Some developersÂ frequentlyÂ createdÂ pull requestsÂ before they were ready to deliver to production.Â Some of these requests stayedÂ open for weeks, and that drove down our repository speed scores.Â 

These long-running pull requests wereÂ used as a discussion point with other squadsÂ to clarify information that was missing in the specs.Â It was alsoÂ a way for developers to communicate changes that would affect otherÂ squads.

Finally, this issue alsoÂ highlightedÂ a tight coupling between squadsÂ that my team wanted to avoid. The goal is forÂ our squads to be autonomous but alsoÂ loosely coupled to each other. The idea is to keep ourÂ microservice architecture very flexible, using APIs between the different services/squads. But when more than one squad beganÂ working on the same pull request, it highlightedÂ an issue that seemed like an architecture/code ownership problem to us.Â If your APIs are well designed, you should be able to make changes at will, without affecting other squads.

After discussing best practices to improveÂ this metric, squads were driven to experiment with pair programming, development on branches, API versioning, and contributing code across repositories.

4. Deployment frequency

Squads that deployÂ more than once per week can fix outages in production fasterÂ because they have the automation in place to deploy changes quickly and easily. They’re also delivering value to customers more frequently.

Finally, they’re more likely to fix newly reported critical security vulnerabilities within a few days because they don’t have to wait for the next scheduled deployment window or implement an “emergency change” procedure.

Our deployment frequency score is based on the number of successful deployments over the last 30 days, with color zero to oneÂ deploymentsÂ red, two to three yellow, and four or moreÂ green.

Initially my team receivedÂ pushback from teams that deliver code to production onlyÂ every couple of weeksÂ or, in some cases, only once per month. Deployment frequency is a key metric, and we were able to use the research from AccelerateÂ to back up the importance of frequent deployments.Â Â 

Promoting more frequent deployments

To further encourage frequent deployments, teams were put on a weekly sprint cadence.Â And early on, we also had weekly playbacks.Â It quickly became clear which teams were delivering value every week and which were not.Â 

Eventually, as the organization grew, my team settled into a pattern of biweekly playbacks so they could fit half of the teams each week into a one-hour session.

All of this led to conversations about how these teams might adopt continuous delivery.Â In some cases, we’veÂ been able to sit with a team and get its CI/CD pipeline set up within a few days.

A red deployment frequency tile also shows us where the team needs to pull down the latest code and check for security vulnerabilities, and hopefully automate that process as well.

5. Deployment stability

Deployment stability is the percentage of time when the most recent build for a given repositoryÂ was successful. On our scale,Â 0% toÂ 50% isÂ red, 50% toÂ 90% isÂ yellow, and 90% or higher isÂ green.Â A developer on our team invented this metric after our developers complainedÂ thatÂ they were spendingÂ too much of their time fixing builds.Â 

Broken builds can be a good thing, whenÂ excellent test automation has stopped a poor-quality change from being delivered to production.Â Not all broken builds are due to code errors; sometimes there’s an infrastructure problem that needs to be fixed.Â Broken builds become a problem when they persist for a long time and start to interfere with developer productivity.

By visualizing broken builds over time on the dashboard, it’s obvious whereÂ squadsÂ need to spend some time cleaning up technical debt and fixing the deployment process.

6. SonarQubeÂ metrics

Most of our repositories have integrated SonarQube reporting into their CI/CD processes, pulling the overall scores for security, code quality, and test coverage into our dashboard.Â They’re displayed at a repository level, squad level, and cross-platform level.Â 

Making these scores visible helps teams ask for more time to improve their scores.Â My team has seen, for example, that oneÂ team improved its SonarQube security score from a DÂ to an AÂ in two days just byÂ implementing the small changes SonarQube recommended.

My team isÂ frequently challenged to defend our goal of 100% unit test coverage.Â Some teams believe they should get an “A” on the dashboard for a lower test coverage score, like 70%. My team stuck to our convictions here, and if a squad is happy with 70% coverage, then they can accept a lower grade.Â Â 

Others point out that it’s possible for teams to game the system by telling the code coverage checker to ignore large swathes of code.Â In reality, there has not been widespread abuse of code coverage “ignore” flags.Â Our developers and code reviewers should have the integrity to be honest about their code coverage.

Understand your goalâ€”and start slow

Your goal should not be to make every tile on the dashboard turn green. You want to see where your squad is performing well and where there’s room to improve. Then you can make an informed decision as to where to invest time.

These six metrics are simple for people to visualize, and they have resulted in positive changes in myÂ organization. But start outÂ small and rollÂ them out graduallyÂ as you explore how these metrics can help your own organization.

[ Get up to speed on quality-driven development with TechBeacon’s new guide. Plus: Download the World Quality Report 2019-20 for lessons from leading organizations. ]

item.title: Quantifying Cloud Security Effectiveness | McAfee Blogs
item.dc:creator: svcselenium
item.description: Letâ€™s start with the good news. Agencies are adopting cloud services at an increased rate. Adoption has only increased in
item.content:encoded:
Letâ€™s start with the good news. Agencies are adopting cloud services at an increased rate. Adoption has only increased in times of coronavirus quarantine lockdowns with most federal, state and municipal workforce working from home. Whatâ€™s even better news is that we also see increased adoption of cloud security tools, like CASB, which is commensurate with the expanding cloud footprint of US Public Sector agencies.

So now we have security tools in place to secure our cloud assets in SaaS, PaaS and IaaS. The next step is to determine what security controls need to be implemented. What DLP policies should the agency adopt? What capabilities of a cloud services should be enabled or disabled to maintain a robust security posture? How does an agency actually go about measuring the effectiveness of the security controls that were implemented? How do we find out how we stack up against our peer organizations?

To answer these questions, McAfee developed MVISION Cloud Security Advisor (CSA). Cloud Security Advisor is a portal that is provided â€œout-of-the-boxâ€ with your organizationâ€™s MVISION Cloud CASB tenant. CSA provides a comprehensive set of recommendations for organizations to prioritize efforts in implementing their cloud security controls. The recommendations are broken down into Visibility and Control metrics. There is also a section that provides quarterly reports on various parameters, which we will discuss in a little bit.

When you first access Cloud Security Advisor dashboard you are presented with a â€œmagic quadrantâ€ that shows your organizationâ€™s security posture relative to other peer organizations on the scales of Control and Visibility and provides a maturity score for both.

There is even an option to select a vertical market to see how your organizations stacks up to organizations in other business sectors.

On the right of the main dashboard are check list items that provide a short description and current progress in following Cloud Security Advisorâ€™s recommendations. CSA scans the organizationâ€™s MISION Cloud environment once every 24 hours. Any changes to MVISION Cloud will be reflected in the next scan. In the screenshot below, for example, we see an environment that is not enforcing controls on publicly shared links in Collaboration SaaS apps.

From here, a security admin can simply click on the check list item and then on Enable Policy. This will automatically take the user to the DLP Policy Templates page to select the appropriate policy for enforcement.

Another powerful capability of MVISION Cloud Security Advisor is providing quarterly Cloud Security Reports. These are accessible from the main CSA dashboard by going to View Reports and then selecting a quarter for which you would like to see the report.

From there we can start examining our organizationâ€™s cloud footprint to identify total number of Shadow IT services discovered that quarter as well as some additional Shadow IT statistics.

Next we can look at IaaS resources in all our AWS, Azure and GCP environments.

We then proceed to look at summary statistics for DLP and access policy violations. Incidents show policy violations of each type detected across all of the organizationâ€™s cloud environments secured by MVISION Cloud CASB.

Next screen shows user behavioral anomalies and threats uncovered by MVISION Cloud UBA machine-learning engine.

The Malware section of the report provides insights into malware uncovered in SaaS and IaaS environments connected to MVISION Cloud.

The Data at Risk report is probably the most pertinent to gauging the effectiveness of the MVISION Cloud CASB solution. This report shows how much of the organizationâ€™s data was at risk and how it was secured using MVISION Cloud CASB. As seen from the image, there is a downward trend, indicating progress is being made to secure organizationâ€™s data.

The Sensitive Data report shows how organizationâ€™s sensitive data is distributed across all cloud services in use by the organization. This report also provides insights into cloud adoption trends for your organization.

The â€œUsersâ€ report is a pivot table of the Sensitive Data report that organizes incidents and policy violations by individual users. Ultimately, the report shows how much of a risk an organizationâ€™s users pose to organizationâ€™s data.

The Mobile Devices report shows incidents for each type of detected mobile device.

The next three pages of the CSA report provide a deeper dive into the data on the front page of the CSA portal we saw in the beginning of this blog. On the Scores page we see the â€œmagic quadrantâ€ with Control and Visibility axis, together with progress relative to previous quarters. Visibility score and Control score, both on a scale of 100, gauge your organizationâ€™s maturity in securing its cloud footprint.

Next, the Visibility metrics page. Visibility metrics measure how well an organization has been doing in gaining visibility into what is out there in their cloud environment and how secure it is.

Finally, the Control metrics page shows how well an organization has performed in placing controls and mitigating security risks for its cloud environment.

And that, in a nutshell, is it. By reviewing the screenshots from the Cloud Security Advisor dashboard you should now have a good idea of the metrics at your disposal to quantify cloud security effectiveness for your organization.

item.title: Zero trust and remote work: Identity and access management is key
item.dc:creator: svcselenium
item.description: In less than a week, the world changed. At the end of March, amid the throes of the coronavirus pandemic,
item.content:encoded:
In less than a week, the world changed. At the end of March, amid the throes of the coronavirus pandemic, the vast majority of states inÂ the US issued stay-at-home orders, resulting in the largest migration to remote working the nation has ever seen.

Before this happened, justÂ 4% of workers spent the majority of their working hours outside the office, and only 43% worked remotely with “some frequency.”

For security teams, the move caused chaos. Sensitive business resources that had, up to that point, only been accessed by workers at the office now hadÂ to be available to employees working from home. While many security experts had talked about the decline of the perimeter for more than a decade, the mass migration to remote working has forced every business to consider how to operate security with a distributed workforce.

Many still are struggling to adjust, saidÂ Chase Cunningham, vice president and principal analyst for security and risk at Forrester Research.

“We’ve seen five years of innovation in three months. Companies are going to move toward this model, and it is up to them whether they work towards it now or continue to skate uphill by keeping everything inside the network.”
â€”Chase Cunningham

“Zero trust,”Â the concept of operating securely with a distributed workforce and without a perimeter,Â has become a necessity for most companies. Not long ago, it wasÂ an aspirational model instead of a requirement.

Here’s why zero trust is so important now, and how you can implement the model.

[ Get up to speed on zero trust security with TechBeacon’s guide.Â Plus: Learn how to conquerÂ zero trust authentication challengesÂ in this Webinar.Â ]

Why zero trust is needed

Surveys have found that anywhere from 70% to 85% of companies with remote workers intend to encourage them to continue to work from home evenÂ after stay-at-home orders expire.Â For instance, business research firm GartnerÂ found that 74% of companies expect at least 5% of their workforce whoÂ previously worked in an office to work from home in the future.

Still, the zero-trust model is not just about accommodating those workers. It is a foundational move in the digital transformation ofÂ the businessâ€”efforts that were already underway before the pandemic, saidÂ Robert MacDonald, director of solutions at Micro Focus.

“The situation has accelerated the need to digitally transformÂ the business to remove the traditional perimeter to be much more fluid, because people are working from everywhere, and they need access to that data regardless.”
â€”Robert MacDonald

For companies struggling with moving to the zero-trust model, here are five recommendations from experts.

1. Zero trust is no longer optional

Moving the focus of security away from the perimeter is no longer an option. Aside from the realities imposed by the coronavirus pandemic and the uncertainty of whether in-office work will be possible on a consistent basis, many companies are looking at moving employees out of the office as a way to cut costs, reduce downtime due to commuting, and improve employees’Â work-life balance.

“I’ve been having lots of conversations about companies reducing how many people are coming to an office in a building,” Forrester’s CunninghamÂ said. If they can cut their on-premises workforce by 25%, they can reduce costs significantly.

“This is one of the few times in history where something that is really terribleÂ can have a massive upside if we leverage carefully.”
â€”Chase Cunningham

[ Learn about theÂ evolution of trusted identities in this zero trust Webinar.Â ]

2. Much of the technology is new

Even just aÂ few years ago, mature technology for implementing zero trust did not exist. While single sign-on vendors existed, the ability to manage corporate resources and access to those resources on a granular level had not advanced enough to scale to large deployments.

The USÂ Department of Defense and other federal agencies have pursued zero-trust principles for more than a decade, with a variety of programs aimed atÂ limiting access to data to only authorized parties, according to a draft zero-trust architecture specification from the USÂ National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).

When these programs were started, “they were limited by the technical capabilities of information systems,” NIST said in theÂ draft. Security policies were largely static and, to get the largest effect for the effort, were enforced at large “choke points”Â that an enterprise could control.

As technology matures, it is becoming possible to continually analyze and evaluate access requests, dynamically and granularly, “to mitigate data exposure due to compromised accounts, attackers monitoring a network, and other threats,” the NIST document said.

3. Don’t expect a single service or product to solve the problem

Zero trust requires a large number of components to workÂ together in an auditable and verifiable way.Â The seven basic tenets, according to the NIST specification, include:

  1. Designating all data sources and computing services as resources
  2. Encrypting all communication end-to-end, no matter the location
  3. Authorizing access to resources on a per-session basis
  4. Allowing security and access policies to dynamically change based on context, state of the client, and current perceived riskÂ 
  5. Monitoring all assets to be in the most secure state possible
  6. Enforcing the temporary and dynamic nature of authentication and authorization
  7. Maintaining visibility into the security of the entire network and business’s resources

The interaction among all these requirements means that a single product or service is not going to be able to deliver a zero-trust architecture to a company, saidÂ Micro Focus’sÂ MacDonald.Â 

“If a single company is saying that they will get you to zero trust, that’s nonsense.”
â€”Robert MacDonald

4. Identity and access management areÂ crucial starting points

The root cause of many breaches is the use of stolen credentials; it’sÂ the second-most common threat action, according to Verizon’s 2020 Data Breach Investigations Report. The most common threat action is phishing, which often also leads to credential compromise.

Almost every company that has suffered a breach has had antivirus software, a firewall, and maybe even an intrusion-prevention systemÂ in place, saidÂ Forrester’s Cunningham.Â 

“Where they fell down was with privilege and access control. If your identity or access store is compromised, that is when a breach can go on for days.”
â€”Chase Cunningham

The lesson is that managing identity and access is possibly the most important part of security, especially in a world of distributed employees, he said.Â 

5. Verify identity and authorization continuously

Managing the initial authentication is not enough. Companies also need to re-authenticate users every time they access a different resource. With technologies includingÂ adaptive authentication, such checks do not have to be intrusive, but should be based on context, saidÂ Micro Focus’Â MacDonald.

“If you only rely on the point of access, there is no check afterward. You want to constantly verify that the user assigned that identity is doing what you think they should be doing. If we just let them in and let them go, then we lose visibility into what actions they are taking on the network.”
â€”Robert MacDonald

As companies adjust to “the new reality,”Â security remains a tough balance. However, pursuing a zero-trust architecture can give companies flexibility in work arrangements, the security of continuous monitoring, and the ability to adapt to whatever the future holds.

item.dc:creator: svcselenium

item.content:encoded:
In todayâ€™s online world, every digital experience is a reflection of your brandâ€”which is why mobile application testing should be at the forefront of your testing strategy.Â 

Whether itâ€™s a picture of a check, a selfie, or a QR code, images can be uploaded to mobile apps for many reasons. Behind the scenes, the application has to do some amount of processing and storage. While creating those images might have been as simple as pointing and clicking for the user, testing image uploads themselves can be more challenging.

Before we dive into how to test image upload functionality, letâ€™s quickly look at some common scenarios that require this type of testing.

Common Use Cases

  • Taking a picture and storing it in a gallery app – Whether itâ€™s a social media app or photo sharing, this use case can span many different types. In its simplest form, it could be taking pictures from the front or back cameras.

Regardless of the application, in order to ensure end users have a delightful experience, development teams need to have the ability to use the device camera for taking pictures so they can complete all testing scenarios. If youâ€™re using a cloud service for mobile app testing, the devices will need to offer some type of Camera Image Injection feature.

What is Camera Image Injection?

Camera image injection gives developers the ability to inject images in their automation testing, so that specific test cases such as apps requiring scanning of QR codes or image scanners, can run on a cloud-based testing service as if it were on an actual device. This essentially provides the application with an image that mocks the use of the device camera.Â 

Testing on Sauce Labs Real Device Cloud

To mimic camera behavior when testing applications on the Real Device Cloud, you need to provide the application with an image that mocks the use of the camera. Sauce enables this with the Camera Image Injection feature. Image injection takes an image (in either .jpeg, or .jpg format) that is stored locally and presents it to the application as if it was read by the device camera. Users can easily test this functionality manually via live testing or insert into their Appium test automation.

Live Testing

In this short video, you can see the uploaded image is used in the app as if the image was taken by the device camera.

Appium Test Automation

In your automated test script, you’ll need to input the desired capabilities specific to Camera Image Injection (see example code snippets here) and incorporate the uploading of the images and opening of the camera.

  1. Start image injection by adding camera instrumentation desired capability command in your test script. Image injection is enabled by the desired capability sauceLabsImageInjectionEnabled.

  2. When you reach the stage in your test session where youâ€™d like to take an image with the app camera, add the image injection method in your test script.Â 

  3. After inputting this code, the application reads the image when it captures a photo. You can change the image by sending the custom command with a different image.
